sen.j: 安城御影（あんじょうのごえい（みえい））は、鎌倉時代の1255年（建長7年）法眼朝円の筆とされる絹本著色親鸞聖人像。
sen.e: Anjo no Goei (or Miei) is a color painting on silk of portrait of Shinran Shonin attributed to Hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) Choen in 1255 in Kamakura Period.
Anjo no Goei (or Miei) is a color portrait on silk of Shinran Shonin attributed to Hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) Choen in 1255 during the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 安城御影（1,276mm×401mm）には、上部に『無量寿経仏説無量寿経』（願生偈）、下部に「正信念仏偈」の讃文がある。
sen.e: Anjo no Goei (1,276mmX401mm) has two sanmon; one is "無量寿経仏説無量寿経(願生偈)" (Muryoju-kyo Bussetsu Muryoju-kyo Sutra (Ganshoge)) in the upper part, and the other "正信念仏偈 (Shoshin nenbutsuge (verses written by Shinran))" in the lower part.

sen.j: 名称の由来は三河国碧海郡安静（現・安城市）に伝来したことによる。
sen.e: The source of the name is the fact that it was transmitted in Anjo (present Anjo City) in Aomi no kori in Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 親鸞24輩（24高弟）真仏の弟子専海が法眼朝円に描かせた。
sen.e: Senkai, who was a disciple of Shinbutsu, who was one of twenty-four high-ranking disciples of Shinran made Hogen Choen paint it, and the Gansho-ji Temple (located in Aza Hongo, Hekoshicho, Okazaki City) owned it and, therefore, it is called Anjo no Goei (written as 安城御影 (or 安静御影))..
sen.cmt: 漢字による表記の違いは文章では説明できないため、漢字を入れた原文にない文を追加しました。

sen.j: 願照寺（岡崎市舳越町字本郷に所在）が所蔵していたため、安城御影（または安静御影）と呼ばれる。

sen.j: 本願寺第3代覚如の長男存覚の記した『存覚袖日記』には、1355年（文和4年）に当時所蔵していた願照寺の照空房から安城御影を見せてもらった時のことが詳しく記されている。
sen.e: In "Zonkaku Sodenikki" written by Zonkaku, who was the first son of Kakunyo, who was the third head priest of Hongan-ji Temple, there is detailed description of situations when Shokubo of Gansho-ji Temple, who owned the goei at that time, showed him Anjo no Goei.

sen.e: In 1952, as tsuketari to Shinran Shonin-zo by monochrome ink painting on paper (Kagami Goei), original and duplicate were designated to national treasure.

sen.e: Two duplicates were produced in the age of Rennyo, who was the eighth head priest, and one was owned by the Nishihongan-ji Temple together with the original and the other was owned by the Higashihongan-ji Temple and designated as the national important cultural property.
